abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Guangxi Urban Environment Project details environmental
            impacts and countermeasures to eliminate or mitigate them
            for three subprojects: 1) The Rongsha Lakes Treatment
            Project in Guilin City replenishes Lake Ronghu and Lake
            Shahu, improves the wastewater collection system, and builds
            a new pumping station. 2) The Chaoyangxi Comprehensive
            Treatment Project in Nanning City renews the Chaoyang
            Stream, betters the city's wastewater and rain
            collecting system, and builds wastewater treatment plants.
            3) The Lijiang Comprehensive Treatment Project in Guilin
            City replenishes the river and protects its dikes, improves
            the sewage treatment system and wastewater collecting
            system, and builds wastewater treatment plants. During
            subproject construction, measures to prevent raised dust
            include: encircling the construction site with braided
            plastic fabrics; storing only earth needed to fill in the
            site, sprinkling water during the dry season when earth is
            stored, loaded and transported; closely covering vehicles
            transporting construction materials like cement, lime, and
            construction refuse; and removing the concrete mixer and
            lathes far from inhabitants, institutions, or schools. To
            prevent and reduce construction noise, workers will abide by
            the city's rules and regulations; avoid using
            noise-making machines at noon or during the night; adopt the
            method of underground pipe-jacking and optimize machine use
            time. Ecological damage to land and trees in the vicinity of
            the construction can be alleviated by enclosing the sites,
            and shortening the construction period. Greenbelts should be
            planted along the open tunnels as soon as they are
            completed. The flow of garbage can be checked by burying it
            in enclosed places like mountain hollows. Dredging will be
            used to counter the effects of heavy metals and other
            pollutants in water bodies. Countermeasures to reduce
            expected negative impacts during the dredging of water
            bodies include: dredging only during the dry season to
            reduce water contained in the sediment and shorten drying
            time; transporting temporarily piled bottom clay to prevent
            its being washed back into the river; building water
            overflow tunnels when encircling banks of piled sediment;
            spreading bactericides to prevent water quality
            deterioration and the multiplication of flies and
            mosquitoes; sprinkling a bleaching solution to destroy
            noisome smells and kill noxious germs; protecting workers
            with gas masks containing activated carbon fiber; and piling
            and covering up sediment from solid wastes to prevent runoff
            pollution and foul smells. During the operational phase,
            sludge produced by the wastewater treatment plant will be
            mitigated by clearing inorganic sand from the sedimentation
            basin, and making mudcakes of the dehydrated sludge to be
            used as fertilizer, if found to be safe, or in a sanitary
            land fill, if proven harmful. Shock absorbers will be used
            too alleviate the noise from the pumping station. To counter
            wastewater pollution, rainwater amounts will be controlled;
            wastewater interception, absorption, and clearing capacity
            will be employed; and the flow of rainwater entering water
            bodies will be controlled and increased to prevent
            eutrophication or diverted into another water body.
